Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Quantifying the Isotopic Signature of Nitrogen Oxides Emissions Sources
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on developing a better understanding of the sources of nitrogen oxide emissions to the atmosphere. Samples will be collected from several key sources such as vehicles, biomass burning, and emissions generated from soils. The fraction of isotopic nitrogen (15N) will be measured in each sample. This will enable ?fingerprints? to be developed for each of the important sources to the atmosphere. Being able to identify the contribution of major sources of nitrogen oxides to the atmosphere has broad implications for addressing environmental issues, such as the formation of smog and acid rain, and for air quality modeling and decision making associated with source reduction strategies. This research will be integrated with a multi-faceted education program to increase the participation of minorities in science research.

A new method has been developed to enable the measurement of nitrogen oxides (NOx) without having the samples subject to fractionation upon collection. The method uses a solution of NaOH with KMnO4 that reacts with both NO and NO2 in the gas phase yielding nitrate in solution. The method has been tested in the PI?s laboratory and found to have a good level of reproducibility based upon repeated measures of standards and samples. A field deployable system is being developed by pairing this technique with a method to determine the fraction of isotopic 15N of the NOx. The resulting characterization of NOx sources will enable tracing the sources of NOx for studies ranging from urban pollution to nitrogen fertilization in ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Variability in the burden of nitrogen oxides (NOx = NO+NO2) is a first-order research question in atmospheric chemistry. NOx concentrations play an important role in determining the oxidizing efficiency of the atmosphere via connections to ozone cycling and OH concentrations. Furthermore, atmospheric NOx is the primary source of nitric acid, a major contributor to acid rain and global nitrogen deposition. NOx is released by both anthropogenic (fossil fuel combustion, biomass burning, aircraft emissions) and natural (lightning, biogenic production in soils, natural fires) sources, which vary considerably in both space and time. This makes it difficult to control the negative consequences of reactive nitrogen (N) in the environment. N (and oxygen) atoms exist in the environment with different stable isotopes ? e.g. nitrogen exists as 14-N and 15-N, which contain equal numbers of protons but different numbers of neutrons in their nuclei, and hence differ in relative atomic mass. This difference in relative atomic mass and neutrons leads to different behavior in the environment of due to chemical, biological and physical processes that can be tracked and quantified. Several studies suggest that variability in the isotopic composition of nitric acid (i.e. nitrate) deposition is related to variability in the isotopic signatures of NOx emission sources. However, the isotopic composition of most NOx sources was poorly constrained. To use the isotopes of reactive nitrogen (N) species to track the impact of these species in the environment we must be able to distinguish signatures associated with different sources.

The projects supported under this research grant aimed to quantify the isotopic signatures associated with NOx emissions from major emission sources in the U.S. We completed field and laboratory studies to investigate isotopic signatures from vehicles in the NE and Midwest U.S., agricultural soils in the NE U.S., and wildfires in the Western U.S. This work required laboratory and field work, and development of new, robust methods to capture gases in the environment without modifying their in situ isotopic compositions, bringing those samples back to the laboratory to complete a suite of measurements. While the original goals of this work focused on NOx, collaborations leveraged our novel approaches allowing us to also explore the utility of isotopes for detailing the influence of other reactive N species such as nitrous acid (HONO), nitric acid (HNO3) and ammonium/ammonium (NH3/NH4) in different environments. Ultimately, we have found that the isotopic signatures can indeed distinguish sources of NOx, HONO and NH3. However, our work also revealed a critical need to understand the changes in isotopic composition of these species that occur with chemical interactions in the atmosphere. Overall, this work produced twelve peer-reviewed publications (with more to come!), covering a range of studies including: new methodologies that were laboratory and field-verified to accurately collect environmental samples that do not modify their in situ compositions; isotopic signatures associated with reactive N emissions in vehicle plumes, agricultural soil emissions under different fertilizer management practices, and wildfires (both direct emissions and in smoke-impacted plumes); new frameworks for tracking the influence of reactive N in the environment through study of the isotopic composition of nitrate and ammonium from urban areas where the deposition of these products affects water quality and ecosystem health - to remote alpine ecosystems where nitrate levels in lake waters are surprisingly high and the influence of atmospheric sources was able to be quantified - to ice cores from the Tibetan Plateau where it was shown that emissions associated with fertilizer use in Asia have been the major driver of nitrate deposition since the pre-industrial period impacting a critical water resource for millions of people.

The education and outreach components of this CAREER proposal included foundational support for the career of an early-career female professor in STEM; provided training of at least 6 undergraduates, 2 Ph.D. students and 2 postdoctoral research associates in research methods, field work, communicating results, and science writing. Recruitment of undergraduate and graduate research assistants emphasized broadening participation in both the scientific enterprise and workforce via connections with organizations such as the Earth Science Women?s Network and the Leadership Alliance. A majority of the students were women from different backgrounds including Native American and Asian ethnicities; low-income and/or low opportunity neighborhoods; and first-generation college or graduate students. A ?learn-by-teaching? program was established to promote exposure of elementary school students in Providence, RI to cutting edge science in the study of atmospheric chemistry, weather, and climate, and to engage undergraduates in outreach and teaching science. The final component of the education and broader impacts plan involved professional development workshops for geoscience postdoctoral scholars and graduate students at major scientific conferences on topics such as navigating grant writing, publishing and communicating research results to wider audiences, and building networking skills necessary for successful careers in scientific organizations.
